I thought that some of you would like to read Poundcake’s report. We still have a long way to go, but we’re making progress, which is the main thing. So happy that the bouncing baby girl is making her return. I also wanted to let you know that today’s $1,325 bill was covered by you all. You have made this scary journey so much easier on us. Thank you. We’ll return to Purdue for a follow up visit on March 15th. Pretty sure we start kidding right around then, so I don’t know if both Josh and I will be able to go. Poundcake will continue to live indoors with us(shucks 😉), probably for the rest of her life. When her catheter is out, she will eventually be able to have play dates with her friends. I know Bernie will be happy. We do have a few things we need to add to Poundcake’s wishlist, so I’ll let you know when that’s updated. It’s also been requested that we get ahold of our local farm store, so moneys can be sent directly to them. This will help us cover things that we can’t get off of Amazon, like straw, pine shavings, Chaffhaye, and that kind of stuff. We’ll let you know when we’ve got that set up. Anyways, thank you. Josh and I couldn’t have done this without y’alls help. You’re the best friends any farmers could ask for. ❤️

Happy 6th birthday, Tootsie aka Tootsie Roll aka Tootie aka Stinky Tootie Booty aka Toots aka Toots McGoots aka Tooter. If you haven’t figured it out, we were very busy on this day in 2012. 😂 Tootie always looks so angry, has a scowl on her face, but she’s a tiny little thing, so she’s hard to take seriously. Super smart little girl, but hates to be petted, though. However, she does love to be brushed, so we always get to bond over that. Every night when I fill the water bowls, she meets me by the hydrant, for a peanut. Goats are creatures of habit. Tooter is expecting her second batch of kids on the 26th. I’m thinking twins.

I know a lot of you are wondering how Poundcake is doing. Well, we decided to take her for a second opinion since her fever came back. The new vet believes she has what is called “Joint-Ill”. It is a bacterial infection that attacks the joints. I had never heard of it. It is usually caused by an umbilical cord that has not been dipped in iodine right after birth. However, we dip all of our kids right away, so Poundcake is a special case. More than likely has to do with her rough start at life and her smallness. The disease causes swollen joints and joint pain and is also accompanied by a fever. A cough doesn’t usually accompany it, but Poundcake is special once again. In some cases, it can be cleared up with treatment(weeks to months). Other cases, they will have joint problems their entire lives. A lot like arthritis. He’s hoping that since we’ve been so on top of it, that she’ll make a full recovery. It is not contagious to any of the other goats. So, that’s what I know. Farmer Josh was the one to take her to the vet earlier this week and said that she was a perfect patient once again. He also said that if she doesn’t start improving, we’d better start shopping for diapers and onesies. I’ll let you fill in the blanks.(and it has nothing to do with a tiny human😂)

A little bit about Georgette: Well....we brought her home in 2010(ish). The top photo is of the day we brought her home. She was in very bad shape. Had a respiratory infection, a terrible case of worms, and was malnourished. She had obviously had no human interaction. The only way to put our hands on her was to corner her with three people and catch her that way. It was about 3 years later....she came up to me and let me put my hand on her back. 3 years without being able to touch her!!!!! Since then, she's quite the changed goat. Loves attention and will just sit there with her head on my lap. She's still not fond of strangers, but the occasional lucky visitor is able to pet her. She's pretty amazing.
Mocha is a good momma to all of the kids. She's very patient, unlike a few of our other moms whom I won't name names.

Here’s your chance to own your very own little piece of Poundcake. $10(US dollars) will get you one of our favorite Poundcake prints, a custom Poundcake button, and a hoofograph of the little lady herself. For those outside of the United States, it’s an additional $2(US dollars). If you’d like drool on your hoofograph, we’ll have to charge extra. 😂 We only have 100 on hand, so it’s first come first serve, and it will be a surprise which print and button you receive.(If we allow everyone to pick their favorites, it’ll be a nightmare for the farmer) So, if you’d like to help with Pounder’s medical bills and also have a little souvenir, you can send $10(extra $2 if you’re outside of the states) to our PayPal account (goatsgonegrazingacres@yahoo.com or paypal.me/ggga) or if you don’t know how to send money directly, just let me know, and I can send you an invoice. You can also send money via Zelle(goatsgonegrazingacres@yahoo.com), be sure and send us your shipping address. Please let us know if you have any questions, and thanks for everything!!! If we do end up with more than 100 orders, we'll order more, it'll just take a little longer to get them shipped out to you.

When it rains, it pours. Sunflower is now being treated for listeria. She’s hardly showing any symptoms, but we’re attacking it, just to be safe. It involves a lot of injections and months of recovery, but we’re optimistic since her symptoms are so minor. None of the other goats are showing any signs, so it’s more than likely not caused by their hay or grain. She probably just ate a leaf with the bacteria. Just one of those thing. Unfortunately, that means she’s being taken off of this year’s breeding lineup. Her health is more important. She is currently in a stall with her daughter, Poppy, keeping her company. I’ll make sure and keep you updated on her progress.

This farmer just about had a heart attack today. I went to do chores in the kidding area & couldn't find Poundcake anywhere. I had just seen her 5 minutes prior, but she was nowhere to be found. I ran around frantically checking every hidey hole in the kidding area and checked all of the kidding stalls at least 5 times. I was convinced that a bald eagle had taken her. Then I checked by the storage barn one last time and found the little turd underneath of it. She had jumped a three and a half foot blockade and was happily grazing underneath the shed. This was a pic of her when she decided to finally show her face. Best hide and goat seek player ever.

Will the Pill went to the vet today too. Let’s just say that there was a problem with his favorite body part. He has what is called “pizzle rot”. New to me. He’s getting daily injections and special treatment on his man bits. He asks that you keep him and his little “pill” in your thoughts.

I have no good news. Poundcake’s heart is larger, and the progress we had made with her arteries and the blood infection is no longer progress. She’s back to the point where she was when we first brought her in December. We don’t have a lot of options because there has not been a lot of studies done on goats with this condition. We are having her blood cultured again, to see if there is a different antibiotic that we can put her on, to possibly help fight off the infection. As of right now, she is back to her normal spunky self and is ready to go home, so that’s what we’ll be doing as soon as she gets blood drawn and gets a new catheter. We’re still trying to remain optimistic, but realize that we’re going in the wrong direction. If she does worsen, we’ll have to decide if it’s time to humanely put her down. But, for now, I’m going to soak up every ounce of love that this little goat has to give. I’m not going to give up hope and I hope that she’s not ready to give up, either. Lots of tears today, so thank you all for the kind words and actions and love. Life is just not fair sometimes.

So, to all of you that contributed to help with her hospital stay and expenses.....thank you from the bottom of our hearts. She’ll have a follow up stay and checkup at Purdue next month. She’ll get a new catheter and also have all of the testing done again, to see how well this course of treatment is doing. Georgette has been hitting the hard stuff again. Grain, that is. Georgette has been on our farm almost longer than any of the other goats. When she came to us, she was skin and bones, had a terrible respiratory infection, and was full of worms. Did I mention she was practically feral? Years went by, and we weren’t able to put our hands on her unless there were 3 of us cornering her. Then one day, it was like a light switch went off and she decided to trust us. I remember the first time she let me pet her, exactly where we were standing and what I was doing. That was almost 6 years ago. She now loves to give me hugs and just rest her head in my lap or on my chest when I’m spending time with the herd. Moral of the story: time, patience, and love......works every time. Oh yeah, don’t forget the snacks.
She still loves to help me with chores and has learned how to activate the motion light in the barn. Have you ever seen such cute help?

Poundcake has now been diagnosed with a heart defect. There is no chance of survival unless she has open heart surgery, and her chance of surviving the surgery isn’t the best. The vet also said that we shouldn’t be surprised if she doesn’t even make it to the surgery. Our vet has never done a PDA repair on a goat before, but is willing to give it a try. If you know of any vet(we’re willing to travel) or university that has more experience, please point us in their direction. The surgery itself is going to cost well over a thousand dollars, but we’re willing to try anything. My heart is so broken. I don’t know what I’m going to do without her.

We have good news! Her echocardiogram showed 40% improvement on her heart valves!!! That means that the infection that they gave a poor prognosis on is being fought off. They want us to continue on the IV antibiotics for another 8 weeks, so that means a new catheter tomorrow. Happy 2nd birthday to our very own Poppy aka Pop-Tart. Poppy and her sister, Shasta, went to their new home when they were about 3 months old. When we called to check and see how they were doing at their new home, they told us that they just didn’t have time for them and weren’t spending any time with them. This instantly broke my heart because our babies are raised with so much love and attention, so we offered to take them back. They returned home and instantly bonded with their momma who they’d been away from for over a month. However, that month away was enough to reprogram Poppy, and she was quite fearful of humans. She’s gotten a lot better, but still isn’t the sweet girl that she was when she left our farm. In due time, she’ll be back to her old self. Goats need love, too, and some people just don’t realize that. Poppy adores her mom so much. You can hear the two having conversations around the goat yard quite often. It’s comical because it usually sounds like her mom is lecturing her.
Gas or happiness......either way, Luna is adorable.

It’s time for a nap before the next mom decides to kid. Zzzzzzzzzzzz. Stella had been in labor since about 9 last night. I spent the night out there with her. As soon as the sun came up, I decided to grain the main herd, and of course that’s when I heard the contraction SCREAM! I ran back into the kidding area, and her water had broke. First baby presented itself completely breach. I saw a tail poking out. Made me laugh. I did have to assist a bit since that’s a tough position. The other two shot right out not too long after the first was born. The first born looks a lot like Pounder. Has the little white spot on her side, just missing that white tipped tail. Looks like brown eyes, though. Pretty sure the other lil girl has blue eyes. And the boy, the dark brown one, I’m thinking has brown eyes. Stella is doing well. Just tired. This is her first set of triplets.
The best lil helper I could ask for.

A lot of information thrown at us just now, but I’ll try my best. The hole in her heart is large and inoperable. There is nothing they can do for it. With that condition, they can live months or even an entire lifetime. It’s the infection in the blood and the mass by the heart that they’re most worried about. They are going to do cultures of her blood over the next couple days and find an antibiotic regimen that will work best. They will put in a catheter, and we’ll be able to administer IV antibiotics at home. Her chance of survival isn’t the greatest, but the doctors say there are always miracles. She’s made it through so much already, I’m hoping she still has some fight in her. She should be able to come home tomorrow or in a couple days. With it being around the holidays, they’re trying to get it all worked out. If you’d like to make a contribution to help towards all of her expenses, you may send money via PayPal. Our account is: goatsgonegrazingacres@yahoo.com Every little bit helps, and we appreciate it so much. I know that some people don’t like to use PayPal, so if you’d like to send a check, our mailing address is: Goats Gone Grazing Acres PO Box 83 Fredonia, KY 42411. Thank you all for the kind words. We read everything, just don’t have time to respond to everyone. I’ll give Pounder another big old hug from y’all. -Farmer Jessi

Happy 3rd birthday to this lil miracle, Miracle aka Baby Girl aka Monkey. Miracle is Poundcake’s aunt. Her mom, Shortcake, passed away due to kidding complications 2 days after Miracle was born. That’s how Miracle became our first house goat. It was a lot different than living with Poundcake. More like living with a two year old who loved to put everything in her mouth. Her favorite was my iPhone charger. Since Miracle didn’t have anyone to protect her from the other big goats once it was time to move outside, we decided that it’d be best for her to live at Josh’s mom’s house, with 3 other kids that she fell in love with from that year. We are still Mom and Dad to Miracle. Comes running when she hears our voices and smells our breath to make sure it’s us when we get to her. Luckily, she’s only 8 minutes up the road, and I can visit whenever I want to.

Happy 2nd birthday, Shasta aka Shasta Pants. If you ever wondered what a smart goat looks like, you’re looking at one. Shasta and I have an obstacle course that she does every night when it is time to close the pasture gate. She runs to each of the obstacles and knows exactly what to do to get her reward peanuts. She’s a smart and independent little girl. Shasta’s mom favors Poppy, so you don’t see Shasta snuggled up with her mom like you do Poppy. You often see her sleeping in a hut or on a spool by herself. I don’t know why, but a lot of times moms seem to favor one particular kid, especially as they get older. Shasta is on the roster to have kids next year. This will be her first time. Yule will be her hot date since Boy Troy is her dad. Her sister and mom will more than likely also be bred, so it should be fun to see all of the families together.

Do you think they're related? Lilly on the left is the mom. She's 13 years old and is retired. She only had kids once on our farm and she had triplets. On her old farm, I don't know how many times she had kids, but she had quints at least twice. Thus, the large belly(never bounces back after that many babies). Dottie on the right is her daughter. Dottie is 8 years old and is retired. We would normally breed her one more time before retirement, but she had pregnancy toxemia the last 2 times, so we decided it was time for an early retirement. Her first kidding, she had triplets. Her other 2 kiddings, she had quads. 11 kids in 3 kiddings....very impressive.

Did I hear somebody say that they’re missing Bernice? Well, how about a dose of Bernice and Luna? Our plan was to integrate the 4 new fainters in with the main herd. But after having Sunflower and Poppy in with the 4 fainters while Sunflower was ill and seeing Poppy going after those fainters like a heat seeking missile(they learn really quickly that they’re fainters and can push them over for fun), we’ve decided to give the 4 fainters their own pasture and barn. We’re in the process of fencing off part of one of our hay fields and will be bringing them in a barn next week. Hoping to have them moved to their new area in a couple weeks, which will give us time to get the kidding area ready for kidding season. Anyway, I need help naming the new fainters’ area. Fainter’s Paradise, Myotonic Mansion......I don’t know. I need your guys’ help. Any ideas?

Happy 6th birthday, Stella aka Baby Stella aka Napoleon. Until Pounder came along, Stella was our smallest kid ever born on the farm. Her two brothers were 3 times her size when they were born. Just the way we like her. She’s due to kid on March 24th. This will be her second kidding. I’m guessing triplets this time.

Happy 1st birthday, Ruby aka Ruby Booby aka Booby(thanks a lot, Farmer Riley, for making that nickname stick). Ruby is one of two kids that we retained last year. Her momma, Rosie, has always been a loner, so we wanted to keep one of her babies as a companion for her. They are practically attached at the hip. Rosie loves her little girl. Ruby is loving, sweet, with a tad bit of orneriness....but that’s the way we like her.

Happy 4th birthday to this sexy goat beast. Boy Troy is a character and a half. There are days when he’ll be my best friend and practically crawls onto my lap for attention, then there are days when I look at him just right, and he’ll faint and fall over. He doesn’t faint very often anymore, is able to control it most of the time, but still occasionally topples over. Boy Troy is not a fan of strangers and if he could speak, I think he’d be running around the yard, yelling “stranger danger”, with every visitor that drops by. He will be a dad again in about a week and a half!!! Looking forward to meeting his babies.

Just got another phone call from the vet. Poundcake does have a hole in the center of her heart. It is inoperable. The other thing they found is a mass in the soft tissue exit of the heart. It is either a tumor or a bacterial infection in the blood, which has caused a buildup. They will be doing a blood culture tomorrow. We won’t know anymore until after they run the culture. She is doing fine after her ultrasound and is happily munching alfalfa. We’ll get to see her at about 10 tomorrow morning.

Happy 3rd birthday, Ziggy!!! Ziggy was born on our farm, but actually travelled all of the way to Florida to be with his new family when he was about 4 months old. One of Ziggy’s new parents fell very ill about a year after Ziggy moved away, so we offered to let him and his two new herd mates move in with us. That way their old owners could always take them back if that chance ever arose and they’d also be able to watch them continue to thrive on this thing we call the internet. So, our herd grew by 3, and we gained 3 of the sweetest goats you’ll ever meet, Ziggy, Milly, and Vinny. Happy birthday, Zig-Man.

She’s feeling better this morning, but she won’t be doing much today, besides resting and watching tv.....and standing on the coffee table.

I have some good news and a whole lot of unanswered questions. She still hasn’t seen the cardiologist, but looking at her films, they’re thinking her heart is going to be ok. We’ll know more after she sees cardio. However, we still don’t know why she has no energy, is losing weight, still limps, runs a fever, is in constant pain, and has an off and on cough. They are running a bunch of tests on her, and she’ll be staying there for the next 5 days or so. You don’t know how hard it was to leave her there. She cried as I walked away. She’s five and a half hours from home, and I’m going to miss her so. Christmas isn’t going to be Christmas without her. Continue to keep her in your thoughts because just the stress of being somewhere new is hard on them. We are staying the night, so I’ll get to see her one last time tomorrow, and they should have some test results back for us.

I know that some of you already know, but we’ve started a Poundcake bucket list. I’m not giving up hope, but in case her days are cut short, we want her to have a little fun. A few things on her list are: having a play date in the house with her bestie, eating an actual poundcake, meeting a celebrity, having a professional photo session with her farmers, and one that we’d like you all to get involved with. We’d really like to get a postcard from all 50 states(and all over the world), from her friends and family. If you’d like to send Poundcake a postcard, our mailing address is GGGA PO Box 83 Fredonia, KY 42411. And I’ve also had lots of folks ask how she’s been doing. Besides that first night being home from Purdue (that was a rough one), she’s been doing really well. A little cough today, but nothing to worry about. We won’t get the results from her blood culture back until the middle of next week, so we’re still doing what we were before, just added the Banamine back into the mix. I’m trying my hardest to stay optimistic and am just loving her up as much as possible. Her good days are encouraging. Also, if you can think of anymore bucket list items you think she should do, let us know. Obviously, traveling is out of the picture(she likes being home where it’s stress free), and the activities have to be fairly laid back due to her condition. We’d love to hear your ideas. ❤️

How about another fresh outta the oven Flower doeling photo? She was born at about 9:45 this morning. Flower was in labor for about 12 hours. Her water finally broke at 9:20 this morning, and her girl made an appearance shortly after that. The little girl did have one of her front legs tucked back and wasn’t in the traditional diving position, so I helped momma out at the very end. She was just having a little trouble getting that shoulder to pass. We got her out within 30 seconds once I gave her a little help. Baby did have trouble nursing for a bit (Mom was a bit of a helicopter Mom and wouldn’t leave her alone long enough to eat), but eventually momma was distracted, and baby girl latched right on. She’s all dried off now, with a full belly and is ready to sleep the night away.

Poundcake would’ve been 11 months old today. We’d already started planning her first birthday party and had a custom tutu made by one of our close friends. We’re pretty sure that Poundcake threw a blood clot, and that’s why she passed away. I was holding her from the moment it happened to the time she left us. I now wish that she was here to hold me as I’m in pain. I miss her dearly. She had been my main focus over the past few months, and all of our time and energy went towards her. In the past 2 months, she had only been out of my sight for about 36 hours total while I was outside doing chores and running just a few errands. I am honestly so lost. I don’t even really know how to function at this point. I’ve never cried so much in my life. I force myself to remember the good things when the ptsd kicks in, but the hurt is terrible. Her mom, Shortie Baby, has been comforting me. She knows. I’ve spent the last two days with the herd, and she just stands beside me, with her hoof on my leg. Thank you all for the kind words. I’m so glad you all got to know this perfect little angel. The world won’t be the same without her.

Miracle!!!! For all of you that are new here, Miracle is Poundcake's aunt. Miracle's mom, Shortcake, died of kidding complications 2 days after Miracle was born, in 2015. Miracle was not supposed to survive the delivery, but she pulled through, and that's how she got her name....Miracle. And Poundcake is named after her late grandma. Pound....because she weighed one pound when she was born. And Cake......after her grandma. We all miss Shortcake, but love our Miracle
